newsitem.title: USA: Canadian spot natgas rises on storage demand, cold.
newsitem.headline: Canadian spot natgas rises on storage demand, cold.

text.p: Canadian spot natural gas prices were stronger in the West on Tuesday, as storage injections continued and cold weather blanketed the Pacific Northwest, market sources said.
At the AECO storage hub, prices climbed nine cents to about C$1.65-1.66 per gigajoule (GJ).
"There's just more buyers than sellers out there," one Calgary-based source said, noting buyers were entering the market for storage supplies.
At Sumas, Wash., prices soared to about $1.35-1.38 per million British thermal units (mmBtu), up about 15 cents from Monday.
Traders blamed the price uptick primarily on cold weather in the Northwest and stronger domestic pricing.
At Niagara, prices eased five cents to about $2.15-2.18 per mmBtu as forecasts called for a return to more seasonably mild weather later this week.
